{"uri": "2024-05-346005003", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "07:04:32", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T07:04:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T02:27:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://news.abplive.com/sports/ipl/mi-vs-srh-ipl-2024-match-preview-probable-playing-11-pitch-weather-report-head-to-head-record-mumbai-vs-hyderabad-may-6-1685333", "title": "MI vs SRH IPL 2024 Match Preview: Probable Playing 11s, Pitch & Weather Report, Head-To-Head Record & More", "body": "MI vs SRH IPL 2024 Match Preview: Sunrisers Hyderabad players Travis Head and Abhishek Sharma during a practice session ahead of their IPL 2024 match against Mumbai Indians. ( Image Source :PTI )\n\nMI vs SRH IPL 2024 Today Match Preview: Mumbai Indians (MI) and Sunrisers Hyderabad (SRH) will square off in match number 55 of the Indian Premier League (IPL) 2024 clash at the Wankhede Stadium in Mumbai on Monday (May 6). While MI would look to finish the season on a high after a disapponting campaign with only 3 wins in 11 matches of the season, SRH would not want to drop points at this stage of the competition, given they are very much alive in the race to the Playoffs\n\nBefore the MI vs SRH IPL 2024 fixture, here are the all the important details related to the match.\n\nMI vs SRH IPL 2024 Date, Time & Venue: Date- May 6 (Monday), Time- 07:30 pm IST, Venue- Wankhede Stadium in Mumbai.\n\nWhere to watch the MI vs SRH IPL 2024 Match: Live Streaming- JioCinema app and website. Live Telecast- Star Sports Network.\n\nREAD HERE | Mumbai Indians (MI) OUT Of IPL 2024 Playoffs Race After Losing To KKR? All You Need To Know\n\nThis could be another one of those high-scoring affairs in IPL 2024. The match will be played at the Wankhede Stadium in Mumbai which is known for its batting friendly conditions. The ball comes to be the bat nicely and with short boundaries, if there is pace on, batter can use it to his advantage. Team looking to bat first would eye nothing less than 180-200, and if they are in a good condition, they would look to push for even more, such has been the high-scoring nature in this tournament. SRH have already posted the highest total in the history of the IPL this season- 287 and they wouldn't mind posting another mammoth score in IPL 2024. They, however, have struggled while chasing and MI's best bet could be to bat first and post a big score to put the opposition under pressure.\n\nALSO READ | IPL 2024 Updated Points Table, Orange Cap & Purple Cap List After LSG vs KKR IPL Match\n\nWeather Report For MI vs SRH IPL 2024 Match\n\nDuring the match hours, the temperature in Mumbai is expected to be around the 30 Degrees Celsius mark, as per Accuweather. on Monday.\n\nPlaced fourth in the IPL points table with 12 points in 10 matches with six wins and four losses, SRH will be desperate to produce an all-round show and make improvements especially in their bowling department.\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nThe Pat Cummins-led side is in the midst of an intense battle between multiple teams who are bidding for spots in the final four, with Rajasthan Royals (16 points), Kolkata Knight Riders (14 points) and Lucknow Super Giants (12 points) placed above SRH.\n\nChennai Super Kings (5th with 10 points) and a resurgent Delhi Capitals (6th with 10 points) are breathing down SRH's neck, a scenario that would force the 2016 winners to shrug off any rust and get ready for an intense mid-table battle.\n\nIf a two-paced pitch at the Wankhede Stadium for the previous clash against KKR was an aberration, the free-flowing SRH batters would look to make merry and pile up a huge score as they have done several times this year.\n\nThe pitches here generally are batting-friendly and short boundary lengths at this venue make scores in excess of 200 a norm, but the MI-KKR contest played out on a sluggish surface last Friday challenged the batters to dig deep.\n\nAlso Read: Win or perish\n\nSRH would be high on confidence having pipped the table-toppers RR by just one run in their previous outing, a game in which their bowlers pulled off a thrilling win.\n\nTravis Head (396 runs), Abhishek Sharma (315) and Heinrich Klaasen (337) remain the enforcers in SRH's batting but South African Aiden Markram would be keen to make a big score of his own, having had a mixed run so far.\n\nNitish Kumar Reddy (219 runs) has emerged as one of the most promising players for SRH in last few games which takes a significant amount of pressure off the key batters.\n\nT Natarajan's (15 wickets) accuracy would be handy for SRH as the left-arm pacer is chasing Mumbai Indians' Jasprit Bumrah (17) for the purple cap.\n\nFive-time winners Mumbai slipped to the bottom of the pool again when Royal Challengers Bengaluru trumped Gujarat Titans on Saturday night.\n\nWith only three wins in 11 matches, MI's challenge is all but over and there is only \"pride and name\" left to play for by their own admission.\n\nHowever, all is not lost as MI's key India players for the upcoming T20 World Cup, Rohit Sharma, Suryakumar Yadav and Hardik Pandya would remain in focus for their individual form.\n\nRohit's all-out aggressive approach has not yielded many big scores whereas the world number 1 T20 batter Suryakumar would be eyeing consistency after a fine half-century against KKR a few nights ago.\n\nIndia vice-captain Pandya has being consistently on the receiving end due to his ordinary form with both bat and ball and also his on-field decisions as MI skipper.\n\nThe all-rounder, however, would be keen to make amends and put an end to the criticism that he has been facing ever since this IPL edition got underway.\n\nMumbai Indians: Hardik Pandya {"uri": "8113058435", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "03:14:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T03:14:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T03:13:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://sportzwiki.com/cricket/mi-vs-srh-dream11-prediction-match-preview-points-table-head-to-head-match-info-weather-pitch-report-fantasy-stats-and-match-prediction-for-match-55-in-ipl-2024/", "title": "MI vs SRH Dream11 Prediction, Match Preview, Points Table, head to Head, Match info, Weather & Pitch report, Fantasy Stats and Match Prediction for Match 55 in IPL 2024", "body": "MI vs SRH Dream11 Prediction: Mumbai Indians and Sunrisers Hyderabad will be taking on each other in the 55th game of the ongoing Indian Premier League 2024 (IPL 2024). The match is scheduled to be played at the Wankhede Stadium in Mumbai on Monday (May 6).\n\nThis article will provide everything you need about the IPL 2024 match between PBKS and CSK. You'll get the MI vs SRH Dream11 prediction, match preview, points table update, head-to-head comparison, match details, weather and pitch report, fantasy cricket stats and our MI vs SRH match prediction.\n\nWhile MI are still mathematically alive in the competition, their chances of making it to the playoffs are as good as over after they lost their last game against Kolkata Knight Riders. It was their eighth defeat in 11 games this season. The Hardik Pandya led-side had reduced KKR to 57 for 5 but still ended up losing the game by 24 runs while chasing 170.\n\nSRH, on the other hand, are well on their way to the playoffs and a win over MI will further boost their chances. In their last game, the Hyderabad-based outfit registered a thrilling 1-run win over table-toppers Rajasthan Royals and will be eyeing another win.\n\nSRH have already defeated MI once this season and will be fancying their chances again. In the first meeting between the two teams this season, SRH had piled up a record total of 277 for 3 before restricting MI to 246/5.\n\nWith six wins and four defeats this season, SRH are at the fourth spot in the IPL 2024 points table. Travis Head, Abhishek Sharma, Heinrich Klassen, and Aiden Markram went all guns blazing after the Mumbai bowlers as they batted first and scored 277 runs.\n\nMumbai were not too far behind as they managed to get 246 runs for the loss of 5 wickets in their 20 overs. The captaincy switch between Rohit Sharma and Hardik Pandya also played a big role as the team was visibly divided into 2 halves for the majority of IPL 2024.\n\nHowever, they will be playing for their pride now as they hold the reputation of being 5-time IPL champions, a record, which has only been equalled by CSK. The men in blue of IPL have had a tough outing this season and are sitting at the bottom of the points table.\n\nHardik Pandya and team will be facing an in-form SRH who have been in red-hot form with the bat. The team in orange have scored more than three 250+ scores in this season so far, including the highest IPL team total ever - 287/3 vs Royal Challengers Bengaluru.\n\nMI were on the road for over two weeks. During that away leg, Pandya and Co. played four matches but could only manage to win one of them, against Punjab Kings. After that they went on to lose three consecutive games against Rajasthan Royals, Delhi Capitals and Lucknow Super Giants.\n\nUpon returning to Wankhede stadium, the MI fans were hoping for a change of luck but it wasn't the case. The five-time champions lost to KKR by 24 runs.\n\nMI have mustered just six points in eleven matches so far. Playoff spot is a far-off dream now but there is still something to play for.\n\n\"I don't think that we don't have anything to achieve from here,\" MI's Naman Dhir told the media on the eve of the match. \"We have to play for our fans and our pride. We would want to win all three matches. Atmosphere is positive in the dressing room. Earlier we were playing to win every match and the intensity is still the same.\"\n\nThe biggest takeaway from the previous match was Rohit Sharma's inclusion in the team as an impact player. MI spinner Piyush Chawla told the media after the match that Rohit had some mild stiffness in the back.\n\nNaman gave an update on Rohit's fitness.\n\n\"Before that match, Rohit had a stiff back. World Cup is also around the corner so as a precaution he played as an impact player. But he is here for practice today so I guess all fit and fine,\" said Naman.\n\nRohit batted in the nets for a long time during the practice session.\n\nMI Playing XI vs SRH\n\nIshan Kishan (wk), Rohit Sharma, Suryakumar Yadav, Tilak Varma, Hardik Pandya (c), Nehal Wadhera, Tim David, Mohammad Nabi, Piyush Chawla, Gerald Coetzee/Luke Wood, Jasprit Bumrah, Nuwan Thushara\n\nSRH Team News\n\nSRH have been a revelation under new captain Pat Cummins. Their batting line-up has created a fear in the opponent's minds with their brutal power hitting.\n\nSRH have been consistently posting 200-plus totals and with the kind of conditions they will get at the Wankhede, they might end up crossing 250 for the fourth time this season.\n\nWankhede is known for big scores the flat decks and shorter boundaries helps the batters to put on an exhibition of power hitting.\n\nOn one hand SRH are scoring big totals but on the other had they have been conceding a lot of runs too. Their bowling has been a cause of concern but their last encounter against Rajasthan Royals would have given them some confidence coming into the Mumbai game.\n\nThe match against Rajasthan went down to the wire as Bhuvenshwar Kumar defended two runs on the last ball by dismissing Rovman Powell. Bhuvneshwar and T Natarajan back in form have certainly strengthened SRH further.\n\nThe 2016 champions will be looking to inch closer to sealing a playoff spot with a win here.\n\nAll eyes will be on the contest between Travis Head and Jasprit Bumrah with the two in-form players itching to assert domination.\n\nSRH Playing XI vs MI\n\nTravis Head, Abhishek Sharma, Anmolpreet Singh, Heinrich Klaasen (wk), Nitish Kumar Reddy, Abdul Samad, Shahbaz Ahmed, Marco Jansen, Pat Cummins (capt), Bhuvneshwar Kumar, T Natarajan, Jaydev Unadkat/Mayank Markande\n\nMI VS SRH Pitch Report\n\nWankhede has always been a batting paradise where big totals are scored and also chased quite easily at times. The short boundaries ensure plenty of big shots. remain in focus for their individual form (Pic: AFP)\n\nA confident Sunrisers Hyderabad will look to produce a dominant show against a frail Mumbai Indians outfit and move up in the Indian Premier League points table when the two teams clash on Monday.\n\nPlaced fourth in the IPL points table with 12 points in 10 matches with six wins and four losses, SRH will be desperate to produce an all-round show and make improvements especially in their bowling department.\n\nADVERTISEMENT\n\nThe Pat Cummins-led side is in the midst of an intense battle between multiple teams who are bidding for spots in the final four, with Rajasthan Royals (16 points), Kolkata Knight Riders (14 points) and Lucknow Super Giants (12 points) placed above SRH.\n\nChennai Super Kings (5th with 10 points) and a resurgent Delhi Capitals (6th with 10 points) are breathing down SRH's neck, a scenario that would force the 2016 winners to shrug off any rust and get ready for an intense mid-table battle.\n\nIf a two-paced pitch at the Wankhede Stadium for the previous clash against KKR was an aberration, the free-flowing SRH batters would look to make merry and pile up a huge score as they have done several times this year.\n\nThe pitches here generally are batting-friendly and short boundary lengths at this venue make scores in excess of 200 a norm, but the MI-KKR contest played out on a sluggish surface last Friday challenged the batters to dig deep.\n\nAlso Read: Win or perish\n\nSRH would be high on confidence having pipped the table-toppers RR by just one run in their previous outing, a game in which their bowlers pulled off a thrilling win.\n\nTravis Head (396 runs), Abhishek Sharma (315) and Heinrich Klaasen (337) remain the enforcers in SRH's batting but South African Aiden Markram would be keen to make a big score of his own, having had a mixed run so far.\n\nNitish Kumar Reddy (219 runs) has emerged as one of the most promising players for SRH in last few games which takes a significant amount of pressure off the key batters.\n\nT Natarajan's (15 wickets) accuracy would be handy for SRH as the left-arm pacer is chasing Mumbai Indians' Jasprit Bumrah (17) for the purple cap.\n\nFive-time winners Mumbai slipped to the bottom of the pool again when Royal Challengers Bengaluru trumped Gujarat Titans on Saturday night.\n\nWith only three wins in 11 matches, MI's challenge is all but over and there is only \"pride and name\" left to play for by their own admission.\n\nHowever, all is not lost as MI's key India players for the upcoming T20 World Cup, Rohit Sharma, Suryakumar Yadav and Hardik Pandya would remain in focus for their individual form.\n\nRohit's all-out aggressive approach has not yielded many big scores whereas the world number 1 T20 batter Suryakumar would be eyeing consistency after a fine half-century against KKR a few nights ago.\n\nIndia vice-captain Pandya has being consistently on the receiving end due to his ordinary form with both bat and ball and also his on-field decisions as MI skipper.\n\nThe all-rounder, however, would be keen to make amends and put an end to the criticism that he has been facing ever since this IPL {"uri": "8114264584", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "18:14:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T18:14:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T18:13:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.dnaindia.com/cricket/report-ipl-2024-suryakumar-yadav-s-century-power-mi-to-7-wicket-win-over-srh-3088316", "title": "IPL 2024: Suryakumar Yadav's century power MI to 7-wicket win over SRH", "body": "Suryakumar Yadav cracked his second IPL century off 51 deliveries as MI beat SRH by seven wickets at the Wankhede Stadium on Monday.\n\nA brilliant counterattack by Suryakumar Yadav and Tilak Varma following a quick loss of wickets powered the Mumbai Indians (MI) to a seven-wicket win over Sunrisers Hyderabad (SRH) in their Indian Premier League (IPL) game at Wankhede Stadium on Monday.\n\nMI is at the ninth spot with four wins and eight losses, giving them eight points. SRH is at fourth spot with six wins and five losses, giving them 12 points.\n\nIn the run-chase of 174 runs, the five-time champions Mumbai were off to a poor start as they lost their top-order of Ishan Kishan (9), Rohit Sharma (4) and Naman Dhir (0) one-by-one to the pace trio of Marco Jansen, Pat Cummins and Bhuvneshwar Kumar. MI sank to 31/3 in 4.1 overs.\n\nThe duo of Suryakumar Yadav and Tilak Varma took it upon themselves to rebuild the innings. At the end of six overs, MI was 52/3, with Suryakumar (11*) and Tilak (9*) unbeaten. In the final over of the powerplay, Suryakumar and Tilak brought some momentum to MI by smashing Cummins for two fours and a six.\n\nSuryakumar continued his assault on pace, looting 20 runs in four balls against Jansen in the next over, with two fours and two sixes. 22 runs came from the over number seven. Surya and Tilak reached their 50-run stand in 27 balls.\n\nHalfway through the innings, MI was 84/3, with Suryakumar (33*) and Tilak (19*) unbeaten. Mumbai reached the 100-run mark in 11.4 overs with a boundary by Suryakumar towards fine-leg region. Suryakumar reached his fifty, his fourth this season, in 30 balls, with five fours and three sixes.\n\nIn the remaining six overs, MI was left with 46 runs to chase at 128/3, with Suryakumar (66*) and Tilak (28*) unbeaten. In the 15th over, Surya continued to keep MI in the hunt with two brilliant boundaries, bringing down the deficit to 35 runs needed in 30 balls. MI was 139/3 in 15 overs. The duo brought up their century partnership in just 62 balls.\n\nIn the next over by T Natrajan, MI got some more boost in the form of two boundaries, one each by Surya and Tilak, which pulled down the deficit to 25 runs in the final four overs. MI reached the 150-run mark in 16.1 overs. In the final three overs, MI needed just seven runs, with Surya blasting Cummins for two fours and a six on the final three balls of the 17th over to reach the score of 96.\n\nSurya hit Natrajan for a huge six in the 18th over's second delivery, ending his innings at 102* in 51 balls, with 12 fours and six sixes. MI ended their innings at 174/3 in 17.2 overs, with Tilak also unbeaten at 37 in 32 balls, with six fours.\n\nCummins, Jansen and Bhuvneshwar got a wicket each.\n\nEarlier, Hardik Pandya and Piyush Chawla's three-wicket hauls restricted Sunrisers Hyderabad (SRH) at 173/8 against Mumbai Indians (MI) in the Indian Premier League (IPL) 2024 at the Wankhede Stadium on Monday. Batting sensation Travis Head and skipper Pat Cummins were the two highest run scorers for the Sunrisers as they helped the visitors put 173/8 on the scoreboard against the hosts on Monday.\n\nAfter winning the toss, MI skipper Hardik Pandya sent the Sunrisers to bat first, and their decision did go in their favour as they dominated the visitors in the first inning. Travis Head (48) and Abhishek Sharma (11) opened for Sunrisers Hyderbad and played a 56-run partnership. However, MI pacer Jasprit Bumrah made the first breakthrough of the game after he removed Abhishek in the 6th over.\n\nSoon after losing the first wicket, SRH failed to make a solid partnership as the MI bowlers dominated the game. Before reaching the 100-run mark in the 13th over, SRH lost four more wickets and stood at 96/5. The second wicket of the inning came after debutant Anshul Kamboj removed Mayank Agarwal (5) in the 8th over.\n\nPiyush Chawla bagged an important wicket after he removed the dangerous Head in the 11th over. The Australian batter missed his half-century for just two runs. Skipper Hardik Pandya's first wicket came after he dismissed Nitish Reddy (20) in the 12th over.\n\nAfter losing early wickets, the Sunrisers must have thought Heinrich Klaasen (2) would take care of the middle order but the Proteas cricketer was removed from the crease in the 13th over by Chawla. The batters failed to stay on the crease for a longer time after the MI bowling attack kept on taking wickets. Shahbaz Ahmed (10) and Marco Jansen (17) were dismissed by Pandya in the 16th over. Later in the 17th over, Chawla picked Abdul Samad's (3) wicket in the 17th over\n\nIn the end, Pat Cummins (35*) and Sanvir Singh (8) were unbeaten on the crease and took SRH to 173/8. Pandya and Chawla picked up three wickets each in their respective spells and led the Mumbai bowling attack. While Anshul Kamboj and Jasprit Bumrah picked one wicket each. Nuwan Thushara was the only MI bowler who failed to pick wickets in the game.\n\nBrief score: Sunrisers Hyderabad (Travis Head 48, Pat Cummins 35*, Nitish Reddy 20; Hardik Pandya 3/31) lost to Mumbai Indians: 174/3 in 17.2 overs (Suryakumar Yadav 102*, Tilak Varma 37*, Bhuvneshwar Kumar 1/22).\n\n(Except for the headline, this story has not been edited by DNA staff and is published from PTI/ANI)", During the run-chase, MI lost 3 quick wickets but a batting masterclass from Suryakumar Yadav ensured MI successfully chased the target. Hardik Pandya stated:\n\n\"We want to focus on playing good cricket, still think we gave 10-15 runs extra. The way our batters batted, that was excellent.\"\n\nHardik Pandya further talked about his bowling and said that he likes to bowl in the right areas and it worked for him against SRH. Hardik Pandya also lauded veteran leg-spinner Piyush Chawla for his heroics. Hardik Pandya said:\n\n\"My bowling, I like to bowl in the right areas, I bowl according to the situation. Bowled in the right areas today and it worked. I was like Chawla had to bowl from the shorter side. He (Chawla) had to be accurate, the margin of errors have become smaller these days for the bowlers.\"\n\nHardik Pandya was left in awe of Suryakumar Yadav's unbelievable batting performance and credited him for the victory over Sunrisers Hyderabad. {"uri": "8114258701", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "18:10:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T18:10:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T18:08:53Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/sports-games/2929625-ipl-2024-suryas-explosive-century-powers-mi-to-fourth-win-of-season-beat-srh-by-7-wickets", "title": "IPL 2024: Surya's explosive century powers MI to fourth win of season, beat SRH by 7 wickets | Sports-Games", "body": "MI is at the ninth spot with four wins and eight losses, giving them eight points. SRH is at fourth spot with six wins and five losses, giving them 12 points.\n\nA brilliant counterattack by Suryakumar Yadav and Tilak Varma following a quick loss of wickets powered the Mumbai Indians (MI) to a seven-wicket win over Sunrisers Hyderabad (SRH) in their Indian Premier League (IPL) game at Wankhede Stadium on Monday. MI is at the ninth spot with four wins and eight losses, giving them eight points. SRH is at fourth spot with six wins and five losses, giving them 12 points.\n\nIn the run-chase of 174 runs, the five-time champions Mumbai were off to a poor start as they lost their top-order of Ishan Kishan (9), Rohit Sharma (4) and Naman Dhir (0) one-by-one to the pace trio of Marco Jansen, Pat Cummins and Bhuvneshwar Kumar. MI sank to 31/3 in 4.1 overs. The duo of Suryakumar Yadav and Tilak Varma took it upon themselves to rebuild the innings. At the end of six overs, MI was 52/3, with Suryakumar (11*) and Tilak (9*) unbeaten. In the final over of the powerplay, Suryakumar and Tilak brought some momentum to MI by smashing Cummins for two fours and a six.\n\nSuryakumar continued his assault on pace, looting 20 runs in four balls against Jansen in the next over, with two fours and two sixes. 22 runs came from the over number seven. Surya and Tilak reached their 50-run stand in 27 balls.\n\nHalfway through the innings, MI was 84/3, with Suryakumar (33*) and Tilak (19*) unbeaten. Mumbai reached the 100-run mark in 11.4 overs with a boundary by Suryakumar towards fine-leg region.\n\nSuryakumar reached his fifty, his fourth this season, in 30 balls, with five fours and three sixes. In the remaining six overs, MI was left with 46 runs to chase at 128/3, with Suryakumar (66*) and Tilak (28*) unbeaten.\n\nIn the 15th over, Surya continued to keep MI in the hunt with two brilliant boundaries, bringing down the deficit to 35 runs needed in 30 balls. MI was 139/3 in 15 overs. The duo brought up their century partnership in just 62 balls. In the next over by T Natrajan, MI got some more boost in the form of two boundaries, one each by Surya and Tilak, which pulled down the deficit to 25 runs in the final four overs.\n\nMI reached the 150-run mark in 16.1 overs. In the final three overs, MI needed just seven runs, with Surya blasting Cummins for two fours and a six on the final three balls of the 17th over to reach the score of 96. Surya hit Natrajan for a huge six in the 18th over's second delivery, ending his innings at 102* in 51 balls, with 12 fours and six sixes. MI ended their innings at 174/3 in 17.2 overs, with Tilak also unbeaten at 37 in 32 balls, with six fours.\n\nCummins, Jansen and Bhuvneshwar got a wicket each. Earlier, Hardik Pandya and Piyush Chawla's three-wicket hauls restricted Sunrisers Hyderabad (SRH) at 173/8 against Mumbai Indians (MI) in the Indian Premier League (IPL) 2024 at the Wankhede Stadium on Monday.\n\nBatting sensation Travis Head and skipper Pat Cummins were the two highest run scorers for the Sunrisers as they helped the visitors put 173/8 on the scoreboard against the hosts on Monday. After winning the toss, MI skipper Hardik Pandya sent the Sunrisers to bat first, and their decision did go in their favour as they dominated the visitors in the first inning.\n\nTravis Head (48) and Abhishek Sharma (11) opened for Sunrisers Hyderbad and played a 56-run partnership. However, MI pacer Jasprit Bumrah made the first breakthrough of the game after he removed Abhishek in the 6th over. Soon after losing the first wicket, SRH failed to make a solid partnership as the MI bowlers dominated the game. Before reaching the 100-run mark in the 13th over, SRH lost four more wickets and stood at 96/5.\n\nThe second wicket of the inning came after debutant Anshul Kamboj removed Mayank Agarwal (5) in the 8th over. Piyush Chawla bagged an important wicket after he removed the dangerous Head in the 11th over. The Australian batter missed his half-century for just two runs.\n\nSkipper Hardik Pandya's first wicket came after he dismissed Nitish Reddy (20) in the 12th over. After losing early wickets, the Sunrisers must have thought Heinrich Klaasen (2) would take care of the middle order but the Proteas cricketer was removed from the crease in the 13th over by Chawla.\n\nThe batters failed to stay on the crease for a longer time after the MI bowling attack kept on taking wickets. Shahbaz Ahmed (10) and Marco Jansen (17) were dismissed by Pandya in the 16th over. Later in the 17th over, Chawla picked Abdul Samad's (3) wicket in the 17th over. In the end, Pat Cummins (35*) and Sanvir Singh (8) were unbeaten on the crease and took SRH to 173/8.\n\nPandya and Chawla picked up three wickets each in their respective spells and led the Mumbai bowling attack. While Anshul Kamboj and Jasprit Bumrah picked one wicket each. Nuwan Thushara was the only MI bowler who failed to pick wickets in the game. SRH is at fourth spot with six wins and five losses, giving them 12 points.\n\nIn the run-chase of 174 runs, the five-time champions Mumbai were off to a poor start as they lost their top-order of Ishan Kishan (9), Rohit Sharma (4) and Naman Dhir (0) one-by-one to the pace trio of Marco Jansen, Pat Cummins and Bhuvneshwar Kumar. MI sank to 31/3 in 4.1 overs.\n\nThe duo of Suryakumar Yadav and Tilak Varma took it upon themselves to rebuild the innings. At the end of six overs, MI was 52/3, with Suryakumar (11*) and Tilak (9*) unbeaten. In the final over of the powerplay, Suryakumar and Tilak brought some momentum to MI by smashing Cummins for two fours and a six.\n\nSuryakumar continued his assault on pace, looting 20 runs in four balls against Jansen in the next over, with two fours and two sixes. 22 runs came from the over number seven.\n\nSurya and Tilak reached their 50-run stand in 27 balls.\n\nHalfway through the innings, MI was 84/3, with Suryakumar (33*) and Tilak (19*) unbeaten.\n\nMumbai reached the 100-run mark in 11.4 overs with a boundary by Suryakumar towards fine-leg region.\n\nSuryakumar reached his fifty, his fourth this season, in 30 balls, with five fours and three sixes.\n\nIn the remaining six overs, MI was left with 46 runs to chase at 128/3, with Suryakumar (66*) and Tilak (28*) unbeaten.\n\nIn the 15th over, Surya continued to keep MI in the hunt with two brilliant boundaries, bringing down the deficit to 35 runs needed in 30 balls. MI was 139/3 in 15 overs. The duo brought up their century partnership in just 62 balls.\n\nIn the next over by T Natrajan, MI got some more boost in the form of two boundaries, one each by Surya and Tilak, which pulled down the deficit to 25 runs in the final four overs.\n\nMI reached the 150-run mark in 16.1 overs. In the final three overs, MI needed just seven runs, with Surya blasting Cummins for two fours and a six on the final three balls of the 17th over to reach the score of 96.\n\nSurya hit Natrajan for a huge six in the 18th over's second delivery, ending his innings at 102* in 51 balls, with 12 fours and six sixes. MI ended their innings at 174/3 in 17.2 overs, with Tilak also unbeaten at 37 in 32 balls, with six fours.\n\nCummins, Jansen and Bhuvneshwar got a wicket each.\n\nEarlier, Hardik Pandya and Piyush Chawla's three-wicket hauls restricted Sunrisers Hyderabad (SRH) at 173/8 against Mumbai Indians (MI) in the Indian Premier League (IPL) 2024 at the Wankhede Stadium on Monday.\n\nBatting sensation Travis Head and skipper Pat Cummins were the two highest run scorers for the Sunrisers as they helped the visitors put 173/8 on the scoreboard against the hosts on Monday.\n\nAfter winning the toss, MI skipper Hardik Pandya sent the Sunrisers to bat first, and their decision did go in their favour as they dominated the visitors in the first inning.\n\nTravis Head (48) and Abhishek Sharma (11) opened for Sunrisers Hyderbad and played a 56-run partnership. However, MI pacer Jasprit Bumrah made the first breakthrough of the game after he removed Abhishek in the 6th over.\n\nSoon after losing the first wicket, SRH failed to make a solid partnership as the MI bowlers dominated the game. Before reaching the 100-run mark in the 13th over, SRH lost four more wickets and stood at 96/5.\n\nThe second wicket of the inning came after debutant Anshul Kamboj removed Mayank Agarwal (5) in the 8th over.\n\nPiyush Chawla bagged an important wicket after he removed the dangerous Head in the 11th over. The Australian batter missed his half-century for just two runs.\n\nSkipper Hardik Pandya's first wicket came after he dismissed Nitish Reddy (20) in the 12th over.\n\nAfter losing early wickets, the Sunrisers must have thought Heinrich Klaasen (2) would take care of the middle order but the Proteas cricketer was removed from the crease in the 13th over by Chawla.\n\nThe batters failed to stay on the crease for a longer time after the MI bowling attack kept on taking wickets. Shahbaz Ahmed (10) and Marco Jansen (17) were dismissed by Pandya in the 16th over. Later in the 17th over, Chawla picked Abdul Samad's (3) wicket in the 17th over.\n\nIn the end, Pat Cummins (35*) and Sanvir Singh (8) were unbeaten on the crease and took SRH to 173/8.\n\nPandya and Chawla picked up three wickets each in their respective spells and led the Mumbai bowling attack. While Anshul Kamboj and Jasprit Bumrah picked one wicket each. Nuwan Thushara was the only MI bowler who failed to pick wickets in the game.\n\nBrief score: Sunrisers Hyderabad (Travis Head 48, Pat Cummins 35*, Nitish Reddy 20; Hardik Pandya 3/31) lost to Mumbai Indians: 174/3 in 17.2 overs (Suryakumar Yadav 102*, Tilak Varma 37*, Bhuvneshwar Kumar 1/22). They have failed to stitch together a complete performance in most of their matches, losing games after excelling in one department of the match.\n\nLike in their clash with Kolkata Knight Riders at the Wankhede Stadium on Friday (May 3) when they bundled out the visitors for 169 as their bowlers used the double-paced wicket to their advantage to restrict them. Jasprit Bumrah and Nuwan Thushara claimed three wickets apiece while Hardik Pandya bagged 2-44.\n\nWith Thushara striking three early blows, KKR were reduced to 57/5 but Mumbai Indians allowed them to recover from there, bringing in spinners Naman Dhir and Piyush Chawla instead of pressing on with the pacers. Venkatesh Iyer scored a valiant 52-ball 70 and shared an 83-run partnership with Manish Pandey (42) as they rescued Kolkata Knight Riders.\n\nChasing 170, Mumbai Indians lost the plot as batters like Ishan Kishan, Rohit Sharma, Tilak Varma, Naman Dhir, and Nehal Wadhera got out cheaply. Suryakumar Yadav waged a lone battle, scoring 56 off 35 balls, and hitting a flurry of shots as he tried to lift them from a precarious 71/6.\n\nHis wicket and the one of Tim David triggered another collapse as Andre Russell and Mitchell Starc shared five wickets between them to hasten the demise of their hopes. Starc claimed three wickets in the 19th over for a final haul of 4-33 as KKR won by 24 runs for their first victory at the Wankhede Stadium in 12 years.\n\nAgreed that the wicket was two-paced but it was also true that some of the MI batters were out to full tosses.\n\nWith six points from 11 matches, Mumbai Indians will hope to win their remaining three matches and salvage their pride even if other results do not go in their favour and help them make it to the Playoffs.\n\nMumbai Indians are going into the match with four successive defeats and considering their up-and-down form, Hardik Pandya's team will have to pull up their socks to restore some pride.\n\nMeanwhile, their opponents for Monday's clash, Sunrisers Hyderabad have everything to play for as they are placed fourth in the standings and still in the running for the playoffs spots.\n\nSRH have 12 points from six wins in 10 matches and are placed fourth in the points table, clubbed together with Lucknow Super Giants behind Rajasthan Royals (16) and Kolkata Knight Riders (14).\n\nSRH need to win their remaining four matches as the race for the playoffs spots is going to be neck-and-neck. The good thing for them is that they have recovered after two successive defeats against Southern rivals Chennai Super Kings and Royal Challengers Bengaluru.\n\nThey travel to Mumbai after a victory over table-toppers Rajasthan Royals. After four successive wins starting with a six-wicket win over defending champions Chennai Super Kings at the Rajiv Gandhi International Stadium in Hyderabad.\n\nUnder the leadership of Pat Cummins, SRH have done well so far in the league with openers Travis Head and Abhishek Sharma in great form and the likes of Nitish Kumar Reddy, Heinrich Klaasen and Aiden Markram complimenting their efforts with superb batting when needed.\n\nReddy has been their find of the season and had struck a 42-ball unbeaten 76 in their last match while Travis Head blasted 58 off 44 balls while Klaasen smashed a 19-ball 42. For them, Travis Head (396), Klaasen (337) and Abhishek Sharma (315) were their top scorers.\n\nT. Natarajan and Pat Cummins are their most successful bowlers so far with 15 and 12 respectively. Bhuvneshwar and Jaydev Undakat have claimed eight wickets apiece.\n\nGoing by the last match played there, the pitch is likely to offer some assistance to the bowlers and considering their strength in this department, the force would be with SRH in Monday's clash.\n\nOverall, Mumbai Indians have dominated the head-to-head series, winning 12 out of the 21 matches played between them while SRH have won nine.\n\nSRH had defeated Mumbai Indians by 31 runs in a high-scoring clash at the Rajiv Gandhi International Stadium on March 27, scoring 277/3 batting first with Klaasen hammering an unbeaten 80 while Travis Head and Abhishek Sharma scoring 62 and 63 respectively. They then restricted MI to 246/5 with Tilak Varma anchoring the innings with 64.\n\nSquads:\n\nMumbai Indians: Ishan Kishan(w), Rohit Sharma, Suryakumar Yadav, Tilak Varma, Hardik Pandya(c), Nehal MI was 139/3 in 15 overs. In the final three overs, MI needed just seven runs, with Surya blasting Cummins for two fours and a six on the final three balls of the 17th over to reach the score of 96.\n\nSurya hit Natrajan for a huge six in the 18th over's second delivery, ending his innings at 102* in 51 balls, with 12 fours and six sixes. MI ended their innings at 174/3 in 17.2 overs, with Tilak also unbeaten at 37 in 32 balls, with six fours.\n\nCummins, Jansen and Bhuvneshwar got a wicket each.\n\nEarlier, Hardik Pandya and Piyush Chawla's three-wicket hauls restricted Sunrisers Hyderabad (SRH) at 173/8 against Mumbai Indians (MI) in the Indian Premier League (IPL) 2024 at the Wankhede Stadium on Monday.\n\nBatting sensation Travis Head and skipper Pat Cummins were the two highest run scorers for the Sunrisers as they helped the visitors put 173/8 on the scoreboard against the hosts on Monday.\n\nAfter winning the toss, MI skipper Hardik Pandya sent the Sunrisers to bat first, and their decision did go in their favour as they dominated the visitors in the first inning.\n\nTravis Head (48) and Abhishek Sharma (11) opened for Sunrisers Hyderbad and played a 56-run partnership. A special knock from Suryakumar Yadav helped the Mumbai-based franchise register their fourth win of the tournament.\n\nMI skipper Hardik Pandya won the toss and decided to bowl first at the Wankhede Stadium. The decision worked in the home team's favor as the Sunrisers Hyderabad scored 173/8 in 20 overs. Chasing 174 for a victory, the Mumbai-based franchise reached 174/3 in 17.2 overs.\n\nNow that the MI vs SRH match is done and dusted, here's a look at the scorecard, award winners and top records emerging from this IPL 2024 contest.\n\nList of all award winners in MI vs SRH, IPL 2024\n\nPat Cummins won the Electric Striker of the Match award for his unbeaten 17-ball 35 at a strike rate of 205.88. The awards for the Super Sixes, Most Fours and Most Fantasy Points went to Suryakumar Yadav.\n\nSuryakumar also won the Man of the Match award for his unbeaten century. Here is the complete list of award winners:\n\nThe SunRisers Hyderabad could not get to a explosive start this time like their previous IPL 2024 match against the Mumbai Indians. Travis Head scored a 30-ball 48, but none of the other top-order batters could touch the 30-run mark. Captain Pat Cummins scored an unbeaten 35 down the order for the SunRisers.\n\nHardik Pandya and Piyush Chawla picked up three wickets each for the Mumbai Indians. Jasprit Bumrah bowled an economical spell of 1/23 in his four overs.\n\nChasing a 174-run target, the Mumbai Indians lost three wickets in quick succession. Suryakumar Yadav then came in and played his best knock of IPL 2024 to guide MI to 174/3 inside 18 overs. Bhuvneshwar Kumar, Marco Jansen and T Natarajan took one wicket each for the visitors.\n\nMI vs SRH, IPL 2024: Top records and stats from Mumbai Indians vs Sunrisers Hyderabad match\n\nThe Mumbai Indians snapped their four-match losing streak in IPL 2024 with this win against the SunRisers Hyderabad. With the comprehensive triumph, MI kept their slim hopes of qualifying for the playoffs alive.\n\nBowling first after winning the toss, MI did well to restrict SRH to 173-8 as Hardik Pandya and Piyush Chawla claimed three wickets each. In the chase, Suryakumar Yadav (102* off 51) struck a sensational hundred to take Mumbai home in 17.2 overs.\n\nMumbai got off to a disastrous start, losing three wickets for 31 runs inside five overs. Ishan Kishan (9) was caught at slip off Marco Jansen's bowling, while Rohit Sharma (4) chipped one straight up in the air off Pat Cummins. Naman Dhir (0 off 9) tried to go after Bhuvneshwar Kumar, but ended up nicking one to first slip.\n\nSuryakumar, however, turned the contest on its head. He took on Jansen in the seventh over and slapped him for two fours and two sixes. The right-handed batter kept attacking the Hyderabad bowlers and brought up his 50 off only 30 balls.\n\nHaving found his rhythm, he was unstoppable and raced to three figures with flurry of big hits. After smacking Cummins for 4, 4, 6, he clobbered a low full toss from T Natarajan over long-off for a maximum to bring up his hundred and Mumbai Indians' victory. Suryakumar was ably supported by Tilak Varma (37* off 32) in an unbroken fourth-wicket stand of 143.\n\nPandya, Chawla restrict strong SRH batting line-up\n\nHyderabad got off to a typically aggressive start as they reached 51-0 at the end of five overs. There was some luck for Travis Head as he was bowled off a no ball by MI debutant Anshul Kamboj in the fifth over, which eventually ended up going for 19 runs.\n\nThe opening stand was broken when Abhishek Sharma (11) edged a probing delivery from Jasprit Bumrah to the keeper. Mayank Agarwal (5) eventually became Kamboj's first IPL victim as he was bowled attempting a slog. Head's luck soon ran out on 48 as he slog-swept a full ball from Chawla to deep-backward square leg.\n\nNitish Kumar Reddy (20) was the next to go, miscuing a pull off Pandya towards cover. Heinrich Klaasen (2) then inside-edged a full ball from Chawla onto his stumps. Pandya dismissed Shahbaz Ahmed (10) and Jansen (17) in the 16th over to reduce Sunrisers Hyderabad to 124-7. The two teams in action on Monday find themselves in pretty much contrasting position on the points table with SRH very much alive in the race to the Playoffs and being the team that has grabbed all the attention because of the the way they have performed, MI are just the opposite.\n\nThe Blue and Gold Brigade just haven't got going in IPL 2024. Usually, batters can trust the pace on this surface and hit through the line. If it's a traditional Wankhede wicket, expect this to be a high-scoring encounter but if it's like the one which was witnessed in the most recent match which was played here where Kolkata Knight Riders (KKR) were bundled out for 169 before MI only managed 145, then it will be a different story.\n\nALSO READ | Indian Premier League (IPL) 2024 Playoff Qualification Scenarios For All 10 Teams\n\nMI vs SRH IPL 2024 Match Prediction- Who Will Win?\n\nAs per Google's Win Probability Metre, MI have a 52% chance of winning this game, compared to SRH who are given a 48% chance. That suggests a pretty evenly contest game. Having said, this hasn't been MI's season at all and they could perhaps give some of the players on the bench a chance, with an eye on the subsequent seasons. In a captivating encounter, MI emerged victorious by comfortably chasing down SRH's target.\n\nBatting first, SRH posted a competitive total of 173/8 in their allotted 20 overs. Travis Head spearheaded their innings with a solid 48 off 30 deliveries, setting a strong foundation. However, despite promising starts, Abhishek Sharma, Mayank Agarwal, Marco Jansen, and Nitish Kumar Reddy struggled to convert their innings into significant scores.\n\nMI's bowlers, Hardik Pandya and Piyush Chawla, shone brightly by picking up three wickets each, curbing SRH's run flow effectively. Despite a late flourish by Pat Cummins, who ended unbeaten on 35 off 17 balls, SRH could only post a challenging yet achievable total.\n\nIn their reply, MI faced early setbacks losing Ishan Kishan, Rohit Sharma, and Naman Dhir cheaply. However, Suryakumar Yadav played a phenomenal innings, smashing unbeaten 102 runs off just 51 balls with 12 boundaries and six massive sixes, guiding MI's chase with authority. Tilak Varma provided crucial support to Yadav, contributing 37 runs off 32 balls. Together, they formed a match-winning partnership that ensured MI comfortably reached the target with 16 balls to spare.\n\nNext up, Mumbai Indians will take on Kolkata Knight Riders at the Eden Gardens on May 11th, while Sunrisers Hyderabad will clash with Lucknow on May 8th at the Rajiv Gandhi International Stadium in Hyderabad.\n\nAlso Read: IPL 2024 Qualification Scenarios: How can Sunrisers Hyderabad qualify for playoffs after loss against MI in Match 55?\n\nAfter the match, Pat Cummins, the captain of Sunrisers Hyderabad, reflected on their performance, stating they were perhaps a couple of runs short at the Wankhede Stadium. Cummins acknowledged the strong performance by Suryakumar Yadav and expressed optimism about their upcoming matches, hoping for more exciting performances ahead, especially when playing at home.\n\n\"Probably a couple short, at the Wankhede you want as many as you can get. You always feel like you're in, the wicket had a little bit in it so we were definitely in the game. I think Sanvir helped us get to that 170 instead of 150, ideally we'd have a bowler. It's T20 cricket, and it doesn't always work out. SKY played really well. We like playing at home, we'll wait and see what's ahead of us. Photograph: BCCI\n\nA confident Sunrisers Hyderabad will look to produce a dominant show against a frail Mumbai Indians outfit and move up in the Indian Premier League points table when the teams clash in Mumbai on Monday.\n\nPlaced fourth in the table with 12 points from 10 matches after six wins and four defeats, SRH will be desperate to produce an all-round show and make improvements especially in their bowling department.\n\nThe Pat Cummins-led side is in the midst of an intense battle between multiple teams who are bidding for spots in the final four, with Rajasthan Royals (16 points), Kolkata Knight Riders (14 points) and Lucknow Super Giants (12 points) placed above SRH.\n\nChennai Super Kings (5th with 10 points) and a resurgent Delhi Capitals (6th with 10 points) are breathing down SRH's neck, a scenario that must force the 2016 winners to shrug off any rust and get ready for an intense mid-table battle.\n\nIf a two-paced pitch at the Wankhede stadium for the previous clash against KKR was an aberration, the free-flowing SRH batters will look to make merry and pile up a huge score as they have done several times this year.\n\nThe pitches at the Wankhede generally are batting-friendly and short boundary lengths at the venue makes scores in excess of 200 a norm, though the MI-KKR contest, played out on a sluggish surface last Friday, challenged the batters to dig deep.\n\nSRH will be high on confidence having pipped the table-toppers RR by just one run in their previous outing, their bowlers pulling off a thrilling win.\n\nTravis Head (396 runs), Abhishek Sharma (315) and Heinrich Klaasen (337) remain the enforcers in SRH's batting but South African Aiden Markram will be keen to make a big score of his own, having had a mixed run so far.\n\nNitish Kumar Reddy (219 runs) has emerged one of the most promising players for SRH in last few games, which takes a significant amount of pressure off the key batters.\n\nT Natarajan's (15 wickets) accuracy will be handy for SRH as the left-arm pacer is chasing Mumbai Indians' Jasprit Bumrah (17) for the 'Purple cap'.\n\nFive-time winners Mumbai Indians dropped to the bottom of the table again after Royal Challengers Bengaluru trumped Gujarat Titans on Saturday night.\n\nWith only three wins from 11 matches, MI's challenge is all but over and there is only \"pride and name\" left to play for by their own admission.\n\nHowever, all is not lost as MI's key India players for the upcoming T20 World Cup, Rohit Sharma, Suryakumar Yadav and Hardik Pandya, remain in focus for their individual form.\n\nRohit's all-out aggressive approach has not yielded many big scores whereas world No. 1 T20 batter Suryakumar will be eyeing consistency after a fine half-century against KKR a few nights ago.\n\nIndia vice-captain Pandya has being consistently on the receiving end due to his ordinary form with both bat and ball and also his on-field decisions as MI skipper.\n\nThe all-rounder, however, will be keen to make amends and put an end to the criticism that he has been facing ever since this IPL edition got underway.\n\nTeams (from):\n\nMumbai Indians: Hardik Pandya {"uri": "8112364986", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "13:07:00", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T13:07:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T13:06:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.crictracker.com/cricket-analysis/ipl-2024-mumbai-indians-strongest-predicted-playing-xi-against-sunrisers-hyderabad-match-55-3466/", "title": "MI XI against SRH | Predicted Mumbai Indians' playing 11 against Sunrisers Hyderabad for 55th Match of IPL 2024", "body": "The hapless Mumbai Indians (MI) are all set to host the formidable Sunrisers Hyderabad (SRH) in Match 55 of the Indian Premier League (IPL) 2024. Having lost eight of their 11 matches so far, MI are currently at the bottom of the points table and are almost out of the playoff race. SRH, on the other hand, have won six of their 10 games and are fourth in the standings, putting them in strong contention for the knockout stage.\n\nThis is the second time this season that the two teams are facing each other and cricket fans will not forget their previous encounter. Records were tumbled in Hyderabad as SRH posted 272 runs on the board - the then-highest-ever IPL total - and MI fought hard to chase it down but fell short by just 31 runs.\n\nSRH have been pulling off similar batting heroics throughout the series, while MI have continued to underperform. Notably, SRH are coming on the back of a thrilling 1-run win over table-toppers Rajasthan Royals, while MI enter after a 24-run loss to Kolkata Knight Riders. The five-time champions will be hoping for a positive result when SRH visit their home turf, the Wankhede Stadium, on Monday (May 6).\n\nIshan Kishan and Rohit Sharma have had a great start to their campaign, often giving the team a blazing start in the powerplay. However, as the tournament progressed, both lost their sharpness in attack, especially Rohit Sharma. The former MI captain has struggled in the last few matches as he has been dismissed for cheap scores.\n\nMeanwhile, Kishan was able to get off to a strong start in most of the matches but failed to capitalize on it. However, the last time MI took on SRH, the two made a powerful start to help their team get closer to the mammoth total.\n\nAlso Check: Orange Cap in IPL 2024- Most Runs\n\nSuryakumar Yadav has had an inconsistent run so far this series, one of the main reasons why MI have struggled to get going. He is considered one of the most reliable batters for MI in the middle order, but this time he did not live up to expectations. Tilak Varma is the leading run-scorer for MI in IPL 2024 with 347 runs. The youngster has been a consistent performer and a major force in MI's middle order.\n\nNehal Wadhera has played some good knocks in the limited opportunities he has had this season. The left-hander brings stability to the middle order and helps them to reach a competitive total. Tim David often bats in the lower-middle order and plays a finishing role. In the previous match against SRH, the Australian big-hitter had scored 42 off just 22 balls.\n\nHardik Pandya is going through a tough time in his comeback season with the Mumbai franchise. His team is currently at the bottom of the table and there has been no significant contribution from his side in either department to lift them up. Notably, his slow knock of 20 off 24 balls was partly the reason why MI were unable to chase down the target of 278 against SRH.\n\nMuhammad Nabi is an experienced campaigner, but his expertise has not been of much use to the struggling MI so far. The Afghanistan cricketer has picked up just one wicket in his last three outings and has not contributed much with the bat as well.\n\nVeteran India spinner Piyush Chawla will lead the spin attack for MI. Chawla recently surpassed Dwayne Bravo's tally of 183 wickets, to become the second-highest wicket-taker of all-time in IPL history. He took a wicket at an economy of just 5.00 in the last match against KKR and will aim to continue his form in the upcoming match as well.\n\nMI's key strength is their pace attack and their spearhead Jasprit Bumrah is in top form, not surprisingly. With 17 wickets from 11 matches, the right-arm pacer is currently the leading wicket-taker in the series. Bumrah had gone for an economy of just 9.00 when SRH batters made a mockery of the bowlers in their previous encounter. Gerald Coetzee is also in decent form but needs to control the run flow. Both will also have the assistance of Sri Lankan pacer Nuwan Thushara, who joins as an Impact Player.\n\nAlso Check: Purple Cap in IPL 2024 - Most Wickets\n\nIshan Kishan (wk), Rohit Sharma, {"uri": "8114277989", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "18:25:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T18:25:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T18:25:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6901960968971252, "url": "https://sportstar.thehindu.com/cricket/ipl/ipl-news/mi-vs-srh-ipl-2024-suryakumar-yadav-century-wankhede-mumbai-indians-seven-wicket-win-sunrisers-hyderabad-points-table/article68147179.ece", "title": "MI vs SRH, IPL 2024: Surya's century lights up Wankhede, dims Sunrisers' top-four surge", "body": "Captain Hardik Pandya's pace and veteran leggie Piyush Chawla's craft put brakes on a sensational Sunrisers Hyderabad batting line-up. Suryakumar Yadav and Tilak Varma's scintillating display with the willow then gave Mumbai Indians a rare win in the Indian Premier League 2024.\n\nRiding on Suryakumar's 51-ball hundred and his unbroken third-wicket association of 143 off just 79 balls with Tilak - the third highest partnership of the season, Mumbai Indians overhauled the target of 174 with 16 balls to spare.\n\nAs it happened: MI beat SRH by seven wickets\n\nWhen Tilak took guard in the fifth over, however, Mumbai Indians was in a spot of bother. With the Sunrisers pace battery having reduced the home team to 31 for three, Mumbai Indians was in danger of letting the bowlers' good work down the drain yet again with another poor show by the top-order.\n\nIshan Kishan (straightened up by Marco Jansen to be caught in slips), Rohit Sharma (miscued a pull off Cummins) and Naman Dhir (slashed Bhuvneshwar to point) could not withstand the wrath. Even Suryakumar struggled against Cummins, failing to put a bat to any of his first three deliveries that swung away from his blade.\n\nBut in the seventh over, Suryakumar changed the complexion by taking on Marco Jansen. In what turned out to be a 22-run over, Suryakumar swung Jansen over fine-leg fence twice with his trademark behind-the-wicket innovations. Then on, Tilak played a perfect fiddle as Suryakumar continued to torment the Sunrisers attack.\n\nHad it not been for Chawla and Hardik's partnership with the ball, MI would have been chasing a stiffer target. | Photo Credit: Emmanual Yogini/The Hindu\n\nHad it not been for Chawla and Hardik's partnership with the ball, MI would have been chasing a stiffer target. | Photo Credit: Emmanual Yogini/The Hindu\n\nALSO READ: MI vs SRH, IPL 2024: Who is Anshul Kamboj, the 23-year-old debutant for Mumbai Indians against Sunrisers Hyderabad\n\nHe even settled the score with Cummins with three consecutive pull shots in the 17th over that brought MI on the cusp of a win and himself on the cusp of a hundred. He achieved both the milestones in the next over with the next ball he faced, lofting S. Natarajan over long-off for a six.\n\nHad it not been for Chawla and Hardik's partnership with the ball, MI would have been chasing a stiffer target.\n\nThe duo picked three crucial wickets - of Travis Head, Nitish KumarReddy and Heirich Klaasen - for just six runs in 11 balls to derail SRH from 90 for two to 96 for five. The duo shared another three scalps in the 16th and 17th overs to put MI on top before Cummins' cameo helped SRH cross the 170-run mark.\n\nLatest on SportstarIPL 2024 Purple Cap standings after MI vs But as skipper Hardik Pandya said at the toss the team needed to play for their pride and their fans, this win would have surely made the supporters happy.\n\nSunrisers Hyderabad (SRH), who had a great start to the season, are slowly starting to falter so close to the playoffs mark. They lost two consecutive matches (against RCB and CSK), won the game against Rajasthan by the barest of margin, and now lost again to the bottom-ranked team. As of now, SRH are positioned fourth with 12 points with a lot to be done to qualify for the knockouts.\n\nSuryakumar Yadav was the difference between both sides on the field on Monday night. The flamboyant 360-degree batter finished the match off with a six, notching up his second century this season off just 51 balls.\n\nMumbai started the chase of 174 with a good pace but soon lost their first wicket when Ishan Kishan edged the ball towards the first slip in the second over. SRH captain Pat Cummins came into the attack and wasted no time in taking his first scalp, dismissing Rohit Sharma in the 4th over as wicket-keeper Heinrich Klassen took a brilliant catch running backwards.\n\nCummins' first four deliveries to Suryakumar Yadav felt like a proper Test cricket battle with all the play-and-miss action taking place. SRH was successful in building the pressure in that over, aiding Bhuvneshwar Kumar in the next to dismiss Naman Dhir for a duck.\n\nStay updated with the latest from IPL 2024, including top contenders for the IPL 2024 ORANGE CAP and IPL 2024 PURPLE CAP. Explore the complete IPL 2024 SCHEDULE, IPL 2024 POINTS TABLE and players with the MOST SIXES, MOST FOURS and MOST FIFTIES in IPL 2024\n\nSoon after the powerplay, SKY decided to take on Marco Jansen and shift the momentum in the home team's favour. He smashed 22 runs in Jansen's second over which included two fours and two sixes.\n\nSKY completed his half-century in 30 balls with a four to Jansen in the 13th over. Suryakumar also became the 2nd batter after Rohit Sharma to record 25 scores of 50+ for Mumbai Indians in the IPL.\n\nOnce Suryakumar got going, there was no looking back. He scored his second IPL hundred and led Mumbai Indians to their fourth win of the season with the help of Tilak Varma on the other end. The duo built a match-winning partnership of 143 off 79 balls.\n\nEarlier, Mumbai Indians had a good start after winning the toss and choosing to field first. The expectations were high from SRH's dynamic opening pair of Travis Head and Abhishek Sharma to give them an explosive start yet again. But the home team managed to keep them to the score of 32 in the first four overs.\n\nDebutant Anshul Kamboj took his first IPL wicket in the form of Travis Head but as luck would have it, it turned out to be a no-ball. All the celebrations turned to disappointment and Head added salt to the wounds by hitting a four on the very next ball which was a free hit.\n\nMI's most lethal weapon, Jasprit Bumrah gave the team the first breakthrough by dismissing Abhishek in the last over of the powerplay. The southpaw tried cutting the short delivery but the ball found an edge and Ishan Kishan took a brilliant flying catch behind the wickets.\n\nTravis Head got a third life and again on the same bowler Anshul as he was dropped on 44 by Nuwan Thusara at deep third man. After coming too close to his first IPL wicket twice, Anshul finally got his first scalp in the same over as he castled Mayank Agarwal.\n\nHyderabad had a very quite first half, especially from their standards. They could only manage 88 runs in the first 10 overs of their innings with two wickets. Head's luck finally ended as he was dismissed by leg-spinner Piyush Chawla in the 11th over. The SRH opener tried slogging one over the mid-wicket boundary but ended up handing an easy catch to Tilak Varma on the boundary.\n\nSkipper Pandya came back for his third over and dismissed in-form Nitish Reddy in the very next over.\n\nPiyush came back and took another wicket of SRH, castling the explosive South African Heinrich Klassen with a googly. Pandya gave two breakthroughs to MI in his final over. Shabaz and Marco Jansen were his victims.\n\nYoungster Abdul Samad also didn't make much of a difference to the scorecard as he was dismissed Piyush at a score of 3.\n\nWith only 136 runs on the board at the 17-over mark and already 8 wickets down, SRH had to bring in their impact player. All-rounder Sanvir Singh replaced opener Abhishek Sharma. They have managed to secure just three wins from 11 outings and need a miraculous turnaround at this stage.\n\nPat Cummins' Hyderabad, on the other hand, have six victories to their name after 10 matches. The 2016 champions are currently placed fourth in the standings. A win here would take them to the third position.\n\nThis will be the second time that Mumbai and Hyderabad will face each other this season. When the two teams met earlier, SRH registered a massive 277-run total at the Rajiv Gandhi International Stadium.\n\nMI did not go down without a fight despite the daunting target. The five-time champions finished 246/5 in 20 overs, suffering a 31-run defeat. The ace opener has scored 326 runs from 11 innings at an average of 32.60 and a strike rate of 154.50.\n\nSharma has also been troubled by left-arm fast bowlers, getting out five times to them. This was Mumbai Indians' fourth win of the season.\n\nSuryakumar Yadav owned the night with a scintillating hundred as he paved the way for Mumbai Indians' victory over Sunrisers Hyderabad in IPL 2024. Having won just three matches in 11 outings before this, Mumbai Indians had their backs stacked against the wall. On top of that, a batting failure had seen them succumb to a loss at home in their last match. They were up against a side that had struck what is now the second-highest IPL total earlier this season. With every odds stacked against them, the five-time champions found a way to bounce back and hand the Sunrisers Hyderabad, one of the teams in contention to make the playoffs, a seven-wicket defeat. Probably such a performance, especially from the bat of Suryakumar Yadav, has come a bit late, but Indian cricket fans would be happy that it has arrived in time with the ICC T20 World Cup approaching. IPL 2024 Points Table Updated With Net Run Rate.\n\nHaving won the toss, Mumbai Indians opted to bowl first and Sunrisers Hyderabad's fiery opening partnership between Abhishek Sharma and Travis Head yielded 56 runs before the former had to make his way back to the crease after edging behind to a Jasprit Bumrah delivery. Debutant Anshul Kamboj thought he had Travis Head only for the no-ball siren to go off and turn his happiness to gloom. He did manage to get the wicket of Mayank Agarwal, who made his comeback in this match. Mumbai Indians kept picking up wickets at regular intervals, not allowing the Sunrisers' batting to gain any momentum whatsoever. Hardik Pandya (3/32) and Piyush Chawla (3/33) did the bulk of the damage in the middle overs before a 19-ball 37-run stand between Pat Cummins and Sanvir Singh saw the visitors post 173/8. This time, though, Suryakumar did not fail to take his team over the line. He and Tilak Varma stitched an undefeated 143-run partnership off 79 balls, which helped Mumbai Indians chase down the target in 17.2 overs. Suryakumar completed the run chase with a six over covers which also fetched him a century, his second in the IPL off 51 balls, a knock that included 12 fours and six sixes. As Mumbai Indians gain confidence from this win, Sunrisers Hyderabad's chances of finishing inside the top four took a blow and now they would look to do their best in the three remaining matches. {"uri": "8112453081", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "14:34:21", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T14:34:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T14:33:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.crictracker.com/cricket-stats-mania/mi-vs-srh-ipl-2024-ipl-records-and-stats-at-wankhede-stadium-mumbai-1619-1412/", "title": "MI vs SRH, IPL 2024: IPL Records and Stats at Wankhede Stadium, Mumbai - CricTracker", "body": "Mumbai Indians (MI) will be hoping that there will be some respite in their dreadful situation when they host Sunrisers Hyderabad (SRH) in match 55 of the IPL 2024 (Indian Premier League), at the Wankhede Stadium in Mumbai. MI are currently last on the points table, while SRH are placed fourth.\n\nSRH were involved in a thriller for the ages against RR in their last match. Fifties from Travis Head and Nitish Kumar Reddy followed by a final impulse from Heinrich Klaasen pushed SRH to 200. RR then lost two wickets in the first over, before fifties from Yashasvi Jaiswal and Riyan Parag then put them back on the track, before some amazing death bowling by Pat Cummins and T Natarajan gave SRH a foot in the door. Bhuvneshwar Kumar who had taken two wickets in the first over itself, successfully defended 13 off the last over as SRH won by just one run.\n\nMI started their latest game, at home against KKR amazingly having reduced them to 57/5. Venkatesh Iyer and Manish Pandey then set on to recover, until a death overs burst only restricted MI to 167. Sunil Narine, Varun Chakravarthy, Andre Russell and Mitchell Starc then shared in the bowling spoils as no batter other than Suryakumar Yadav did anything of note for MI slumping them to their fourth consecutive defeat.\n\nThe reverse fixture at Hyderabad was the first in a very long line of matches that tumbled batting records left right and centre. The record for the fastest IPL fifty for SRH was broken twice in the same innings, first by Travis Head, then by Abhishek Sharma. SRH broke even more batting records, but most importantly, broke the then record for the highest team total in IPL(a record they would once again break further in the season). MI tried to fight and put on a fine batting display losing only by 31 runs given the huge target in front of them. MI will look to move away from the bottom of the table and break their losing streak.\n\nWankhede Stadium is known to be a batter-friendly pitch, but in the last match, it showed a new form where it was heavily helping the bowlers and posing challenges to the batters. This may not necessarily persist, but it is likely that it will stay thereabouts. This pitch will not necessarily churn out a surface that will let SRH post 277 again, but typical batting friendliness associated with the Wankhede Stadium will stay.\n\nOut of 114, 61 matches have been won by the team batting second. The average first innings score at this venue is 170 without any no results.\n\nThe Wankhede is very likely to provide support to the bowlers more than it has been. The bowlers will be heaving a sigh of relief as they will be able to contribute to the match. The batters need to be careful rather than just throw their wickets away as batters from both sides did here in the last match. MI's bowling form issues will also be plaguing them. While SRH's bowling will be brimming with confidence after some excellent showing at the death propelled them to a 1-run win. The important matchups are Jasprit Bumrah vs Abhishek Sharma, Piyush Chawla vs Heinrich Klaasen, Rohit Sharma vs Bhuvneshwar Kumar, Suryakumar Yadav vs Pat Cummins, Tim David vs T Natarajan.\n\nKumar has dismissed India's all-format captain just once in the IPL. Rohit though, has scored 81 runs in 61 balls at an average of 81 and strike rate of 132.78. This match-up will be crucial in the powerplay.\n\nThe other Sharma of note in this contest has managed only 8 runs in 10 balls at a strike rate of 80 while being dismissed once at an average of 8. Sharma is currently leading the strike rate charts this season, and this battle will again put his skills to the test.\n\nOn a pitch that wouldn't be extremely helpful to batters, MI's most consistent and arguably the most skilled batsman Suryakumar Yadav will be key to their chances. If he had received some support in the last match, the story could have been different.\n\nHeinrich Klaasen's good form will again be the fulcrum of SRH's batting considering the recent drop in form of all their other batsmen. "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.orissapost.com/srh-eye-consistency-in-must-win-ipl-clash-against-frail-mi/", "title": "SRH eye consistency in must-win IPL clash against frail MI - OrissaPOST", "body": "Mumbai: A confident Sunrisers Hyderabad will look to produce a dominant show against a frail Mumbai Indians outfit and move up in the Indian Premier League points table when the two teams clash in Mumbai Monday.\n\nPlaced fourth in the IPL points table with 12 points in 10 matches with six wins and four losses, SRH will be desperate to produce an all-round show and make improvements, especially in their bowling department.\n\nThe Pat Cummins-led side is in the midst of an intense battle between multiple teams who are bidding for spots in the final four, with Rajasthan Royals (16 points), Kolkata Knight Riders (14 points) and Lucknow Super Giants (12 points) placed above SRH.\n\nChennai Super Kings (5th with 10 points) and a resurgent Delhi Capitals (6th with 10 points) are breathing down SRH's neck, a scenario that would force the 2016 winners to shrug off any rust and get ready for an intense mid-table battle.\n\nIf a two-paced pitch at the Wankhede Stadium for the previous clash against KKR was an aberration, the free-flowing SRH batters would look to make merry and pile up a huge score as they have done several times this year.\n\nThe pitches here generally are batting-friendly and short boundary lengths at this venue make scores in excess of 200 a norm, but the MI-KKR contest played out on a sluggish surface last Friday challenged the batters to dig deep.\n\nSRH would be high on confidence having pipped the table-toppers RR by just one run in their previous outing, a game in which their bowlers pulled off a thrilling win.\n\nTravis Head (396 runs), Abhishek Sharma (315) and Heinrich Klaasen (337) remain the enforcers in SRH's batting but South African Aiden Markram would be keen to make a big score of his own, having had a mixed run so far.\n\nNitish Kumar Reddy (219 runs) has emerged as one of the most promising players for SRH in last few games which takes a significant amount of pressure off the key batters.\n\nT Natarajan's (15 wickets) accuracy would be handy for SRH as the left-arm pacer is chasing Mumbai Indians' Jasprit Bumrah (17) for the purple cap.\n\nFive-time winners Mumbai slipped to the bottom of the pool again when Royal Challengers Bengaluru trumped Gujarat Titans Saturday night.\n\nWith only three wins in 11 matches, MI's challenge is all but over and there is only \"pride and name\" left to play for by their own admission.\n\nHowever, all is not lost as MI's key India players for the upcoming T20 World Cup, Rohit Sharma, Suryakumar Yadav and Hardik Pandya would remain in focus for their individual form.\n\nRohit's all-out aggressive approach has not yielded many big scores whereas the world number 1 T20 batter Suryakumar would be eyeing consistency after a fine half-century against KKR a few nights ago.\n\nIndia vice-captain Pandya has being consistently on the receiving end due to his ordinary form with both bat and ball and also his on-field decisions as MI skipper.\n\nThe all-rounder, however, would be keen to make amends and put an end to the criticism that he has been facing ever since this IPL edition got underway.\n\nTeams (from):\n\nMumbai Indians: After electing to field first, SRH bowlers put in a brilliant display to restrict their opponents to a paltry total of 136/7. SRH's 277/3 against MI in Hyderabad in the 2024 season is the second-highest total in IPL history.\n\n2. Courtesy of the commanding win, MI moved one spot up the ninth position in the points table.\n\nAfter being asked to bat first, SRH notched up a respectable total of 173/8 in 20 overs. Travis Head top-scored for them with a knock of 48 (30), while Pat Cummins played a brilliant cameo of 35* (18) to finish the innings on a high. Hardik Pandya and Piyush Chawla starred for MI with the ball, scalping three wickets apiece.\n\nSRH pacers then bowled magnificently with the new ball and reduced MI to 31/3 in 4.1 overs. Rohit Sharma (4), Ishan Kishan (9), and Naman Dhir (0) were back in the dugout without scoring much.\n\nSuryakumar Yadav and Tilak Varma joined hands at this juncture and weathered the storm by batting sensibly. As soon as the opportunity presented itself, Suryakumar latched on and smashed the bowlers all around the park to inject momentum into the chase.\n\nThe World No. 1 T20I batter was in full flow as he hit a blistering 51-ball century and helped MI cruise to the target in just 17.2 overs. Tilak Varma supported him with a handy knock of 37* (32).\n\nFans on social media enjoyed the IPL 2024 match between MI and SRH on Monday night. They expressed their reactions by sharing hilarious memes on social media platforms like X and Instagram.\n\nHere are some of the best memes related to the game:\n\n\"We were probably a bit short\"- SRH captain Pat Cummins after loss against MI in IPL 2024 match\n\nAfter the conclusion of the match, SRH skipper Pat Cummins reflected on the loss, saying:\n\n\"We were probably a bit short with the bat. Little bit in there on the wicket early. I always thought that the wicket had something about it. Having Sunny out there helped us get to 170.\"\n\nHe added:\n\n\"A quick bowler would have been great but I don't think that would have made a difference. It's T20 cricket and doesn't really work out the way you want. SKY took the game away for us. Interestingly, Sharma registered the record for scoring the most runs by a debutant in an IPL innings.\n\nAlthough Agarwal looked in great touch after his partner's dismissal, Madhwal also sent him to the pavilion in the 17th over. {"uri": "8112474184", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-05", "time": "14:56:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-05T14:56:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T14:55:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.cricbuzz.com/cricket-news/130346/battered-mi-face-another-uphill-task-against-powerhouse-srh", "title": "Battered MI face another uphill task against powerhouse SRH", "body": "Bhvneshwar Kumar has been going at more than 13 an over in the death overs. It was largely due to a stroke of luck that Rovman Powell missed a full toss to hand SunRisers Hyderabad a one-run victory in the SRH's previous game. The win underscores the unpredictability or, as they say, the funny nature of the Twenty20 format. The Royals needed 12 runs off the last over, and two off the last ball.\n\nThat win may have put their campaign back on the rails. Still, SRH have been one of the standout sides this season with their explosive openers - Travis Head and Abhishek Sharma - setting the stage on fire and fast bowling unit, led by Pat Cummins, working like an optimally functioning apparatus. The best feature yet has been the inspiring captaincy of Cummins, who has managed to handle the young Indian players efficiently.\n\nA rare vulnerability for the Hyderabad side, as it's been observed, is their lack of a Plan B, rather contingencies. They normally rely heavily on aggressive batting, particularly through their openers. And in instances where this approach doesn't produce the expected yields, they've struggled to adapt and recalibrate their gameplan. Spin bowling has emerged as another notable weakness, despite the presence of legend Muttiah Muralitharan in the coaching staff. As they prepare to face Mumbai Indians at the Wankhede on Monday evening, these are areas the home team look to exploit.\n\nThe Wankhede Stadium has traditionally been a high-scoring pitch, except for the recent exception seen in the last game, versus Kolkata Knight Riders. It wouldn't be surprising if Monday's match turns into a run-fest, reminiscent of their season's initial encounter in Hyderabad where Mumbai Indians had mounted a strong assault on SRH total and had come close to chasing down the record-breaking total of 278.\n\nA lot will depend on the performance of the openers from both teams.\n\nFor Mumbai Indians, their openers have struggled to survive the PowerPlay overs in numerous games. Rohit Sharma and Ishan Kishan have been dismissed early too often, with Rohit falling six times and Ishan seven times within the first six overs. This inconsistency might be one of the key factors to their underwhelming performance this season. They may face a stronger challenge from SRH pacers, Bhuvneshwar Kumar, Pat Cummins, T Natarajan, Jaydev Unadkat and Marco Jansen, who have all been in good nick. How the MI openers, mainly Rohit, handle the quality SRH pacers will be a point of interest from MI point of view and Indian point of view as well.\n\nFor SRH, this match holds significant importance in their quest to qualify for the playoffs. Currently standing within striking distance with 12 points from 10 games, they require at least two more victories in their remaining four matches. As for MI, with their playoff chances now virtually over, the big question is whether they will opt to rest Jasprit Bumrah, arguably the standout bowler of this IPL season.\n\nWhen: Monday, May 6, 19:30 IST\n\nWhere: Mumbai Indians vs Sunrisers Hyderabad, IPL 2024, Wankhede Stadium, Mumbai\n\nWhat to expect:A lot depends on the nature of the pitch. Otherwise a batting strip, the Wankhede surface was tricky to score in the last game a couple of nights ago. Easy or difficult to bat, the captain winning the toss will choose to field because of the dew factor.Anything less than 200 will not be easy to defend.\n\nHead to Head: MI 12 - 10 SRH. The face-off figures, overall, are not too stark but Mumbai Indians enjoy an edge at the Wankhede Stadium, 5-2. Travis Head (48) and Abhishek Sharma (11) opened for Sunrisers Hyderbad and played a 56-run partnership. The Australian batter missed his half-century for just two runs. Later in the 17th over, Chawla picked Abdul Samad's (3) wicket in the 17th over.\n\nIn the end, Pat Cummins (35*) and Sanvir Singh (8) were unbeaten on the crease and took SRH to 173/8. Pandya and Chawla picked up three wickets each in their respective spells and led the Mumbai bowling attack. While Anshul Kamboj and Jasprit Bumrah picked one wicket each. Nuwan Thushara was the only MI bowler who failed to pick wickets in the game.\n\nThe Mumbai-based franchise need to make 174 runs to win the match infront of their home crowd. But we're not thinking that far ahead,\" Cummins said.\n\nSunrisers Hyderabad (Playing XI): Abhishek Sharma, Travis Head, Mayank Agarwal, Nitish Reddy, Heinrich Klaasen (Wk), Abdul Samad, Shahbaz Ahmed, Marco Jansen, Pat Cummins (C), Bhuvneshwar Kumar, T Natarajan.\n\nMumbai Indians (Playing XI): Ishan Kishan (Wk), Rohit Sharma, Naman Dhir, Suryakumar Yadav, Tilak Varma, Hardik Pandya (C), Tim David, Anshul Kamboj, Piyush Chawla, Jasprit Bumrah, Nuwan Thushara.
